utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: A Fox News alert, in case you're just turning on the news and haven't looked at the internet. The Dow had a dismal day, a dramatic record tumble of 1,175 points, erasing all the gains for the year. Fox Business senior correspondent, Charlie Gasparino, bring us up to speed on what happened. Charlie? All right. I guess we do not have Charlie. You guy's 401(K)'s and your investments getting slammed?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: This is the thing, so having been the press secretary that had the most dramatic stock market ups and down.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, what do we do?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Everyone should just remain very calm. Probably buy, right, if you're being smart.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Dana, the only thing lower than the stock market is Jesse Watters voice from the hangover he has.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I saw you reading the teleprompter, and when you got to the numbers, your brain froze. You didn't know what to do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's why I'm not on Wall Street. I'm in television.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I was trying to help you out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I needed a lifeline there. All right. So what do we do? Do we sell, do we buy? I think everyone buys. No one knows why either that this thing is tanking. I guess.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: We have Charlie now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Charlie, save us please.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Save Jesse.

utterances.speaker: CHARLIE GASPARINO, FOX BUSINESS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: This is called a puke, guys. There's nothing nice you could say about what happened here. What you have is the markets reacting to the possibility of higher interest rates, bigger deficits, leading to even higher interest rates, more inflation because the economy is revving up, and it's trying to digest all of that. As it's digesting that, it is getting sick. And you have what we've had over the last couple of weeks. I will say one thing, President Trump did a massive tax cut. When we do something that big, you may get some inflation but, guess what, corporate balance sheets should be better. We're going to get some job growth. That -- and our deficit should at some point, when the economy starts growing again at a 3.5 percent rate, which a lot of people think it will, that deals with the deficit which keeps down the interest rates. So in my view, OK, I'm not an economist. I've been to a lot of these market corrections. But in my view, this thing is temporary. The one thing I will say, someone should tell Trump to stop talking about the markets. It's not a good thing to be touting the market going up because they always correct. I mean, from a political standpoint, he should stick to the economy, which obviously is getting better.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, I don't think he's going to listen. I think he's going to continue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. We'll take it from there. Thanks a lot. All right. Now to our other top story, much more important, it took 52 years, but the wait is finally over. Philadelphia finally Super Bowl champs.

utterances.speaker: AL MICHAELS, NBC SPORTS
utterances.utterance: Brady under pressure. Launching one for the end zone. It's a jump ball and it's incomplete. And Gronk was the picker. And time runs out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Amazing game. I knew they were going to win. I called it. Predicted it on the show. We can even pull the tape. Eagles beat the Pats for the first time ever winning 41-33, first Super Bowl victory. Entire city of Philadelphia handling it, as you would expect, with class.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Eagles!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, God. All right. What a night for backup quarterback Nick Foles, absolute hero this post season, outplayed Tom Brady in Minneapolis, winning the MVP. Nick, I love you. Thank you. And God has certainly blessed the Philadelphia Eagles.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I love them. I love them. I love every player on the team. An amazing victory. Juan, let's just talk about the game for a second, and I want to play this highlight for you. This I think encapsulates everything. And a great line of the whole thing was Brady can't catch and Nick Foles can. Here's a little play they've dialed up for Brady. Little trick play. Right off his hand, OK? Guy can't catch. That was a critical possession right there. That would have been a first down and keep the drive alive. Brady can't do everything now. And then we have Nick Foles. They dialed up a flea flicker, that directs that flea flicker fourth and one right before the half. Fourth and goal, and that puts them ahead going into the second half. I think it takes a lot to call that play in that situation. Juan, what did you think?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I just loved it. You know what's interesting to me about the Brady thing is that people are now criticizing Bill Belichick, the genius coach of the Patriots, because, you know, his quarterbacks hand was injured. It had been injured and he was been wearing gloves. I think there was no glove on the right hand last night. But, you know, to ask the guy to go out there and catch a pass at 40 years old and - - gosh, what if he had gotten hit, some linebacker came across and crunched him. It would not have been a celebration in Boston. But anyway, the other play in which both catches it, to me, I thought, boy, that's high risk, fourth down. I'm surprised they went for it. And then to do that, you've got to take your hat off to the Philly coach.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Doug Pederson had a great scheme and they executed it perfectly. Dana, your mascot theory, correct.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm 6 for 6.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Every year. Yes, 6 for 6. So follow me. What is a flea flicker?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When they like have the ball in the back and they pitch it to someone else.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've never heard that. I want to -- about the controversial touchdown.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Which one there's two?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There were two?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Where the one the catcher becomes the runner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. He actually broke the play. We've got a lot of lucky calls.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You mean the receiver?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Receiver? Well, he caught the ball.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This not yet the end, America. If you think you're watching.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know why Jesse came to me next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can I talk about the most important thing in the night?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: People are like, I just became really stupid watching.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. I want tell you about the worst thing from last night is the Philadelphia fan who actually ate horse poop. I don't know if you saw that

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think we have that. Hopefully we don't have that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This man will never had cordial relations again. He can't have a job or a family. You could look it up.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Why would you bring that up?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you why I bring it up, because if you laugh when you watch these events, you're a hypocrite because we do these shows where we talk about Antifa and looting and how bad it is when you destroy public and private property.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And somehow we find this kind of behavior after sporting event acceptable. This is not acceptable behavior. You don't have any role in the team winning. It's not an achievement on your part. And go to destroy things is disgusting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't know what it's like to be a Philly fan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think we're going to give them a little slack.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I knew you were going to say that. I mean, they have been waiting for it for long to get some kind of victory here. Obviously, everybody knows that the Philadelphia Eagles fans, this is the way they roll. Win or lose, this is the way they roll. Yes. But as a former prosecutor, I'm not going to be hypocritical. In fact, I think it's inappropriate. We don't need to be lighting things on fire.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We don't need to be flipping buses. But at least, unlike, you know, Antifa, they didn't stab a horse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's true.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: . but they ate from one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, they did something with a horse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Now let's talk about some of the performances. Pink, OK, she had the flu. And I think she paid respect to the red, white and blue. Here is her rendition.

utterances.speaker: PINK, MUSICIAN
utterances.utterance: Home of the brave

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. So Greg, you didn't like that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, no. How dare you. No, no. The one thing I don't like is when they change the note at the end to surprise you, like we're going to go high. No, I'm going low. But you know it's interesting is we didn't have the clip of her when she spit her lozenge out onto the head of a sick child. I couldn't believe she did that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is fake news.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you think of that performance?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I like Pink and I like the guy that sang before, America the Beautiful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a nice rendition.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He was excellent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I like the children's choir with him. I like it when they bring the community out for the game.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was great. And I think we have some footage of Justin Timberlake. He did the halftime performance, and people liked it and some people didn't. Let's see it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So they had Prince out there in the hologram, what did you think, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it wasn't a hologram. In fact, that would have been -- apparently, Prince objected. That's what he said. He said that if people did that he would consider it demonic. He doesn't like it. HE doesn't think it's a good idea. He thinks when Natalie Cole was doing it with her dad, Nat King Cole, he thought it was wrong. He said if he was supposed to play with Duke Ellington, he would have been alive at the same time. But I happen to think the holograms are pretty cool. I remember being in Vegas and seeing that Michael Jackson thing, and this is unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's actually Michael Jackson.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think what they wanted to do, but given that they knew people were going to criticize it, they just went with the screen. It was pretty good. I don't think it was like the most memorable halftime show. It didn't match the equipment malfunction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: See, now to that point, I think it would have been more fair because J.T. was on his best behavior. The hologram should have been Janet because why is he there and she's not there. That strikes me as a bit sexist. And the wardrobe was like straight out of a house party from the '90s. I didn't understand it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He wanted another nip slip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I can't say. Who would want that? I just think it's unfair that he's there and she's not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's look at some of the ads, here's the Giant's ad which got a lot of attention. Let's see that one.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you something, this could be love because I've had the time of my life, though I never felt this way before.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, what did you think?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I loved that move.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He did.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, no, I would like to do it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You like to be hoisted up like that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. It's fun, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very, very smooth move.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, I thought that was a really good commercial. In fact, the dancing was better than the Justin Timberlake piece. I don't know. You know, I didn't think like the Justin Timberlake thing was that good. Prince performed better.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. You liked the Justin Timberlake performance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But I apparently -- I keep liking things that nobody else likes. Like the Joe Kennedy speech. So, I'm 2 for 2. But I just thought it was entertaining. I liked that ad. The Mannings were pretty funny.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a good ad. I think it cost about $5 million for that one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Maybe they could put that into their recruitment for next year team.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think so. I think the Giants needs a little help. That's good, Dana, that you actually knew the Giants for that ad.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Excellent move.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Stay right there, much more to come on The Five. Breaking new developments on the memo when we return.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. That we know about.

utterances.speaker: REP. ADAM SCHIFF, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: The interest wasn't oversight. The interest was a political hit job by the FBI in the service of the president. The goal here is to undermine the FBI, discredit the FBI, discredit the Mueller investigation, do the president's bidding.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Adam Schiff, the ranking member of the House Intelligence Committee, still on a tear about the GOP memo that alleges the FBI and DPJ abuse the FISA process to surveil former Trump campaign advisor Carter Page. Democrats want their own version out to the public and there could be a vote on that soon. Meanwhile, the president called Schiff one of the biggest liars and leakers in Washington who must be stopped today. The congressman is firing back. Mr. President, I see you've had a busy morning of executive time. The primary author of the memo, Devin Nunes, piling on his Democratic colleague:

utterances.speaker: REP. DEVIN NUNES, R-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: If you look at what they've done over the course of the last couple of weeks since we put together our memo so that we could make sure the American public discovered the FISA abuses that occurred, they continue to leak out bits of pieces of information to create narratives that quite frankly have one thing in common, they're always false. Mr. Schiff knows that he's spreading false narrative there. But that's not new for him. He's spread false narrative the entire time.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. So the president, Dana, calling him a liar and a leaker who must be stopped today.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know. So over the weekend I tried to take a step back and I figured let's just -- I'm going to let all of this settle and then read a couple more things when I start on Monday just to see where people are. And I feel like it's -- we're at the same place that we were on Friday except that the Democrats have sort of advance their agenda by, one, responding to the president the way they had after he -- punching or counter punching, I have lost count. I do think that this question of whether the underlying documents are going to be revealed is still an open question. On Friday night, Devin Nunes was on Bret Baier's show for an exclusive interview, and Bret asked him if he had read the underlying documents and he said no. But that Trey Gowdy had -- the congressman from South Carolina, overseeing the oversight committee. And I'm wondering about if the intelligence committee folks are not all read in on exactly what's happening underneath, should those documents actually be released to all of us because I don't know what the context is and I don't know if it's a really good idea to start disseminating to the public information that is supposed to be for investigations. I think it's kind of dangerous. The other thing, I just feel like a lot of the timeline doesn't make sense to me. Especially that the memo talks about Carter Page and the FISA warrant in October 2016 when he left the campaign a month before, in September, and then according to the timeline the counterintelligence investigation started three months before that. So I'm not even sure what Carter Page could have even told anybody on any sort of wiretap that would have been relevant to the Trump campaign if he'd left. So, I think there's a lot of open questions.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. So Greg, Dana thinks, perhaps, it might be an imprudent escalation to then try to now release the Democratic side and go back and forth.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think the Democrats should be allowed. I just wonder about these underlying documents.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The underlying documents like perhaps, obviously, could have some national security implications.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: First, to state the obvious, this is another example of team sport politics. Reminds me -- I think we did a segment on The Five, what was the color of the dress and some people saw the color of the dress as gold.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One was gold -- I think blue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And the other was blue. So one side will always see this one way, one side will see the other. Having said that, Andrew McCarthy, I think really nailed it down in National Review. He responded to Gerald Nadler's letter and he says it's not about Steele being reputable in his dossier. It's not about him being -- he's an upstanding guy. It's not about that. It's about his sources. Remember, he didn't write the dossier. He simply delivered it. So the FBI and the DOJ should have been more -- put more emphasis on that because anybody, a capable person, could put together a report on you with unvented sources. Are you happy that the government used a capable person -- that that's OK with you that they used anonymous sources saying crappy stuff about you. So that's important. But the think that kind of gets me is the Dems -- you keep hearing like, we're releasing this memo, it's a constitutional crisis. How can that be a constitutional crisis and trying to unseat a president in a general election not be a constitutional crisis? I think that -- I think trying to steal an election from the American public is a constitutional crisis. Releasing and, obviously, a memo that has some kind of political opinion in it, let's be honest, it's done by a Republican, there's two sides. So, that is far from a crisis. But somehow generating and ginning up this scandal to steal an election, that's a crisis?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or could be a crisis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. Who ginned up a scandal? The scandal was that the Russians interfered in our election.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's no collusion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I don't know but I'm just telling you that's the real.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Russians interfere in everything. And -- no, we know that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So we should minimize it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, this is about collusion. I'm waiting for the collusion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, I'm just saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you don't have a clear-cut case on collusion and you try to impeach Trump and something happens, you've got a big problem on your hands. It's 67 million people who are going to wage war.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me tell you, I mean, you can portray this as some kind of coup, but the coup would have been if, in fact, we have a candidate running as an agent of a foreign government.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you have nothing there.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: There's no evidence.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What ifs are beautiful, they are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There's no what if without Russians interfering in this election.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They interfere in everything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There's no what if about the Russians favoring Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You can't blame the president for that. He didn't call up and say, hey, Russia, interfere with the election and can you choose me over Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, what about Donald Jr. going right to Trump Tower with a Russian and saying I'm looking for dirt on Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Where did the dossier information come from? Russians.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, please. Let's go back to Dana's point.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I want to make sure he's still alive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Totally makes no sense. Devin Nunes' attempt to say that the timeline bits, and this is the basis, because, guess what, they already were looking at Carter Page from 2013.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And why were they looking at him? He was actually cooperating with the FBI.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, because the Russians tried to recruit him, Greg

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, and he cooperated. He cooperated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He may not be the brightest guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg, you are looking under the table in order to avoid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How dare you, why would I look under the table?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Why not release the Democrats. You guys are always for transparency.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm for it. Do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But Donald Trump says he is vindicated.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's straw man, Juan. That's straw man.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, Donald Trump is a straw man?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're creating a straw man argument. I'm for releasing the memo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: My goodness, this is getting crazy. So -- make less sense, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Obama officials used fake information and got the court to justify spying on the Trump campaign. They lied to the court, Juan. It's a lie of omission.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The dossier was the reason for the spying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They did not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The dossier was kept from the judge. They didn't say it was paid for by Hillary.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. I thought the argument was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, they didn't say that the dossier was paid for by Hillary. It was written by Steele. Why didn't they tell the judge that, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because they knew they would never have gotten the spying done if it wasn't for that. That's why.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you know how weak you are? Because.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Weak? We just won the Super Bowl.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm all for that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wait. Again, we must separate the fans from the players.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: How weak you are, Juan. It is not a scandal on your side. Why is everybody getting demoted? Why is everybody retiring early?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Strzok, Page, all these people -- McCabe, all these people on that side must be guilty of something because they're actually now getting in trouble. The other thing is you're spying on Carter Page for all these years because of collusion.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, hasn't been charged.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And he was cooperating.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He hasn't even been charge, Juan. Where is the dirt? There's no dirt. Now there's more memos coming, so that's why you guys are getting very nervous.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But it is not remotely clear, well, none of it is, but that anything that the government would have been listening to with Carter Page, which she's not even on the campaign anymore, would even relate back to the Trump campaign or the Trump family in any way because he wasn't involved. So maybe there was a problem in getting the warrant and that needs to be looked into, but I also think that the Trump family at this point, I don't know why you would be concerned about Carter Page being listened in on because he wouldn't have known anything.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: If you want to learn more about Carter Page, then you should watch the Ingraham Angle tonight because he's going to be with Laura. That's a piece, isn't it? I'm going to flea flick of this. Ahead, Trey Gowdy talked to a lot of people with his surprise decision to leave congress and his explanation might surprise you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Trey Gowdy is leaving Congress, apparently to spend more time with his hair. I kid. I like the guy. But look at him over the years: He's got a Mohawk, goatee, sideburns, then a beard, the he adds glasses and gets rid of the beard. The guy has more looks than Lady Gaga.

utterances.speaker: Sunday, Gowdy says he's leaving politics because he's lousy at it
REP. TREY GOWDY, R-S.C.
utterances.utterance: I was a pretty good prosecutor, I think, but I've been a lousy politician. I see multiple sides of a single issue, and the fact that someone disagrees with me does not make me challenge their love of the country. It doesn't make me believe that they're corrupt. I've got a lot of friends on the other side of the aisle. I think the manner in which we get places matters, and in politics, too often, winning is the only thing that matters. And look, every hero I have has lost, every one of them. So losing is not the worst thing in the world. Not knowing what you believe and not caring enough about it to fight for it, that's the worst thing in the world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now underneath that cowlick, he has a point. He's lamenting tribalism: the name calling, the smearing of intentions by mind-reading adversaries, all driven by team sport politics. Take the memo controversy. It was the Super Bowl for political Poindexters. Everyone took sides even before reading the damn thing. Of course, no one in the media seemed to mind tribalism before, when only one side fought to win. For the left, the politics was always personal and deemed their opponents, the right, as evil. Now the right has learned from the left, and Republicans are now as feisty as the lefties of old, fueled by a president who may be the least ideological one I've ever seen.

utterances.speaker: The result
utterances.utterance: A fiery feedback loop where one side accuses the other of divisiveness, which leads to endless counter accusations of the same thing. Yet, simply agreeing that we're all guilty of this might help solve the problem. Will that ever happen? Who knows? Divisiveness is easy and it's profitable, for it feels good to point a finger and label people. And if you disagree with me, you're probably a racist, homophobic traitor. It's true. Kimberly, where do see him going? Maybe a style segment on "FOX & Friends"?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. Come on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like him, though.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm a fan. I'm a fan of his. I think he's really bright. He was a phenomenal prosecutor. He had a great reputation. You know, he handled a large, you know, volume of material and really stuck with it in terms of the Benghazi hearings. And I think he's being a virtuous person, and I like what he had to say in terms of being able to see all sides of an issue. And because someone disagrees with you doesn't mean that they're a bad person or their politics or their intentions, you know, should be questioned. So I'm excited to see what he does next. I don't know. Maybe here, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, a lucky guy. Hey, you know, Dana, every time we hear about the assessment of intensity and tribalism. Every time I think about it, then I think about the past. We've had assassinations and civil wars. So is this kind of -- is this idea that we're being divisive a bit overwrought? We did have an actor kill a president. You know?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. I remember when I talked to Mitch McConnell last week. He said, "Let me put everyone's mind at ease." And he went back and said they used to actually beat each other up...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... on the floor. And I think that Trey Gowdy seems very relieved. This is a decision that he's wrestled with for the last couple of cycles, because he realized, I think, early on that, "Wow, this might not be for me." There's a lot of different ways that you can serve your country and be a public servant; and you don't always have to run for office. It's the endless fund-raising, the inability to actually do what he wants to do, which is the law. But he is somebody that you would certainly want as your own personal lawyer. If you -- if he decides to go into law.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I may need one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You would want him as that. You'd want him as a neighbor or a teacher or a friend. And I think he's going to try to teach a little bit, as well.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God, Dana. Like a neighbor, a friend.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I'm a big fan. Ever since the Benghazi hearings, when he would be willing to talk to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And you didn't have to -- and he would give it to you straight, that was certainly welcome and different. No wonder he didn't fit in.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He would be a good member of a book club, too. Don't you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, a book club member.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think we're going too far here. Juan, I think the conflict is heightened, because Republicans have learned from the Democrats on how to fight. Don't you think that's true?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You guys were -- you guys, in the '60s, were so quick...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In the '60s.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Everybody -- everybody you disagreed with was evil. It started with the Vietnam War.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let's go back to the Civil War. But I'm just saying...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Democrats, right? Slavery.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't see -- to me, Trey Gowdy, you know -- by the way, I think a very competent prosecutor. But what he did during Benghazi, two years of beating up on Hillary Clinton and then coming to the conclusion there's nothing here. I mean, I don't understand it. I like the fact that he now says you don't have to, you know, turn your opponents into devils. I think, boy, but now he's leaving, and he's one, by the way, Jesse, unbelievable to me, but 41 Republicans who are leaving this Congress. Nine committee chairmen, including people like Trey Gowdy who does have respect. As I say, I don't like what he did with Benghazi, but he does have some respect as a man who knows the law, a man who could have been one of President Trump's considerations for attorney general. But now you see all these people fleeing. Guess why they're fleeing? There's an erratic president, and there's a chance the Democrats are going to have a big November this year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, can you tie this into the Super Bowl?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I don't think -- I don't think Gowdy is leaving because he's going to lose his seat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like the hair shots. Can we put the six hair shots back? I want to pick my best one. I think the one on the upper left, if you want to DVR it back, was probably the best look. There it is right there with the scruffy goatee. The Benghazi hearings, Juan just said that, you know, nothing came of it. Basically, we found out that they didn't protect the consulate on the eve - - on 9/11's anniversary, couldn't save our own men and women because they didn't have assets in place, and then lied to the American people and to the victims' families to their face and said it was about a video when they knew all along it was a terrorist attack. I actually think he got to the bottom of that. He looked relieved, because all you do is dial for dollars. I heard they, like, put you in a room for, like, four hours a day and you fundraise. That sounds terrible. I mean, the swamp stinks. I'd want to get out of it, too. He's probably going to get a nice paycheck pretty soon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Uh-oh. Shall we move on?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A special surprise addition to Team USA's Olympic delegation. That's next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It touched a lot of hearts to see the parents of Otto Warmbier at President Trump's State of the Union address last week. Their son's memory honored at the Capitol. Otto's tragic story retold again to shine a light on the brutality and grave threat posed by the North Korean regime that tortured him. This week, Fred Warmbier will travel to the region with Vice President Pence to attend the Olympic opening ceremonies in South Korea. Mr. Pence says Fred and his wife remind the world of the atrocities happening next door. And Greg, I think this is a real show of diplomatic strength, because the South Koreans are apparently laying it on real thick to welcome the North Koreans and make feel all good about -- we don't want to normalize. So bringing Mr. Warmbier with him, the vice president is basically forcing all of the media to cover that story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a powerful, symbolic gesture, and it perfectly counters the inclusion of North Korea and its propaganda pep squad that they're going to be putting up there. So every time North Korea is up there at the opening or closing ceremonies, or whenever they have athletes participating, the networks are going to show the dad as a reminder of what the world is like under the rock of that hermit kingdom. We have to turn the rock over. Because you're going to see the best part of that rock during the ceremonies. So you've got to remind people there's bugs under that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it's good when you use people and their personal stories as a rallying cry for a policy or something like that. We had the Kate Steinle situation, and you had Kate's Law. You had Jessica Lunsford, and you had Jessica's Law. Now Otto, I think, is a perfect person, his father to go out there and remind everybody about how disgusting and despicable the regime is. We haven't really had a situation like this since the cold war where the Olympics had that, you know, that nationalistic competition, even though North Korea is not really competition. We'll wipe them out. But it really kind of hones the country's and the world's attention around evil. And it was the evil empire back in the '70s and '80s. And now it's this evil -- Axis of Evil, one of them -- regime up there. And I just -- I just hope -- he's not being used. A lot of people say this guy's being used; he's being exploited. He's not. He's in this. He wants to be part of this, and I'm glad Mike Pence extended the invitation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, what about that, as a father? He basically is saying, "I'm not -- I am going to take this opportunity to try to prevent this from happening to anybody else."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know that he can prevent it, but I mean, boy, what a horrible story. What happened to his child is just -- it's unbearable. So I mean, if he wants to go, feel free. The question to me is what are we setting ourselves up for, you know, going forward? You know, there have been stories about how the Pentagon has been criticized by the White House for not sending over possible military scenarios. And then you hear from the back that the generals don't want the White House to act precipitously in terms of attacking or giving a bloody nose to North Korea, and even somebody who was under consideration to be ambassador, oppose that kind of policy and then withdrew his name from consideration. But I know that, from what we've been told, the North Koreans are going to have big military parades and going to make a show of power in addition to which they are marching in with the South Korean delegation. So, you know, it looks to me like there will be all this pretty, gauzy stuff about North Korea at this moment, and I think Warmbier would serve as a nice antidote to that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, I agree. Kimberly, last thought to you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. You know, it was a really moving moment. I found myself just, you know, looking at the family and really looking at their faces and looking in their eyes. And you can just see that it's just palpable, the pain, the suffering, the loss in just the way his mom's face looked. How it's still so real every morning when she wakes up and every night when she goes to bed. It's her first and last and final thought. And his father looking over at his wife. I mean, it's just -- it's unspeakable. But you know, I applaud President Trump for doing so much to try to get him home, and at least they did get to see their son one final time. I think they're, you know, incredibly symbolic of the American spirit and of patriotism. And you know, we're all tied and connected in this together, and it's a very real reminder of the savagery of the North Korean regime that we should never forget about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Indeed. OK, we're going to move on. Jimmy Kimmel has a theory on why so many late-night hosts are liberals. Conservatives aren't smart enough to do his job.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Boo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That one, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You'd be hard-pressed to find a late-night host these days who's not taking constant cracks at Republicans. Why so many liberals? Jimmy Kimmel has a theory.

utterances.speaker: JIMMY KIMMEL, LATE-NIGHT HOST
utterances.utterance: It also just so happens that pretty much every late-night talk show host is a liberal. And that's because it requires a measure of intelligence. Not a ton, not a tremendous amount of intelligence, but you do have to be over the baseline.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So is he implying that the conservative side of the country is stupid? Unintelligent? It appears so. What do you think, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: First of all, that's what happens when you're in a comfortable space. He's being interviewed by these wonky, beta male fan boys, so he kind of goes a little bit further than maybe he would. But this is also what happens when you come to politics late in life. It creates a false confidence that's inversely proportional to your actual knowledge.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's so true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It is. If he is only sure of his stance -- he's only sure of his stance because he hasn't moved from the emotional position to a factual position. Everybody is like this. I was like this in my 20s when I got into politics. I thought -- and also, both sides are guilty of this. They rely on the intelligence insult. I look at tweets about Juan. Like, if they don't like what Juan says, they called him an idiot, which is not an argument. It's not an argument. And clearly, Juan is not an idiot. He's a very intelligent person. So it's -- rather than call somebody an idiot, which the left does and the right does, you might want to envision yourself on the other side and try to make a strong argument for their argument and then take it apart, which is a lot smarter than this.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They teach you that in speech and debate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true. It's called the steel man. And -- but he's -- he's in an immature portion of his political life. And maybe he might grow out of it. You're seeing in the world of podcasts the mix between right and left, people interviewing each other. Not getting -- like everybody treating each other with respect. Dave Reuben (ph), Jordan Peterson, the Weinsteins, they all work together, and they don't second-guess the intellectual superiority. They don't try to say that they're intellectually superior. And I think that's what -- what he needs to learn, and he probably will. Or not. Who knows? Who cares?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Kimberly, he actually had on conservatives, people who disagree with, you know, a pathway to citizenship for the DACA, for the DREAMers, and had them talk to DREAMers. So it seems like, you know, he's willing to hear from other sides, from the other side.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, I mean, that's not him -- yes, it's his show, but that's not him actually doing it. But look, I think this is really just about kind of ratings and developing his own niche. He's actually been able to do quite well. He started to resonate, remember, during the health care debate. And he was taking on some conservatives, and that became sort of his area, his sweet spot where he seemed to generate some buzz and some interest. So you're seeing him continue down the path, just because it's proved to be successful for him, and there's dividends that have paid off. And I think it's really that simple and formulaic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Jesse, he has said, you know, if -- if conservatives don't like his criticism of Donald Trump, don't watch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's fine. You can change the channel. Watch FOX. I support that. He was doing "The Man Show" before this. Does anybody remember "The Man Show"?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Very popular.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't think that was very highbrow. He was, like, bouncing on trampolines with women in bikinis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But they had Adam Corolla, who was awesome.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he was good, too.

utterances.speaker: It takes wit, and it takes a good personality and decent interviewing skills to be a late-night host. But let's be honest
utterances.utterance: network executives hire people in the comedy and entertainment space, and most of them happen to be liberals. Most conservatives don't go into that space for different reasons. So I don't think it's very deep. But I do think he's getting a little cocky, because he did, you know, land some punches with the health care deal. But in all honesty, I might actually have to invoke "The View" card now, because I do want to be on his show eventually. So I'm going to hedge and say he's very great.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What would you be on his show about? This is very interesting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe things go well for mem here at FOX and he might invite me one time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are things going badly right now?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't think I'm good enough at this point to get the invite.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, come on. We're going to root for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Some of the funniest people I know are conservatives. And they're -- they're smart. You can't be funny without being smart.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I think that's so true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So why -- so why is it that none of the hosts are conservatives?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know, but that's the...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "The G.G. Show," mister.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It also says, like, why aren't -- why don't conservatives go into academia? I mean, there's just choices.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, also because they have all the entertainment people and the liberal Hollywood guests go on there. So that's why.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a great point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" is up next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing." Greg, here's how I lost my voice last night.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Touchdown! Touchdown! Woo! Woo! Yes! Yes!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, and I made a bet with Martha MacCallum. And here it is, and you will see the results on her show.

utterances.speaker: MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: It is a good match. The Eagles and the Patriots is, you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's going to be. And you know what? If the Eagles win, I think you should wear an Eagles jersey on the set. How about that?

utterances.speaker: MACCALLUM
utterances.utterance: OK, I'll do that. I'll do it for the last block.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And for my last block on "The Five," I will wear a Pats. I won't be doing it, but for the interest of the wager.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I was right. I will not be doing it, because they had a great game.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Such confidence. You know, by the way, just so you know...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ... she can't stop winning, because she was actually there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She was. I was not. And it's fine. I enjoyed myself.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's me. Uh-oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Go ahead, K.G. Chew your food.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I can hear her chewing it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to do it. Doritos has announced plans to release new tortilla chips especially for the ladies. The female-friendly version of popular chips will make less of a crunch noise when you eat them. Actually, I don't like that. They're going be a little bit smaller in size, and the single-serve bag will be able to fit inside your purse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you serious?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They should be called Doritas, not Doritos.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's sexist.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The global chief executive of Pepsi, who owns Doritos, thinks that, unlike men, women do not like to crunch loudly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't mind if I crunch. I just don't like to listen to other people crunch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is true. All right. Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's going to be a problem. All right. Time for this.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Mail It In Monday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Mail It In Monday." I'm going to keep it as simple as possible. Just roll it. This is a huge stag dropping by a Skalett (ph) Hotel's bird feeder for a snack. I really don't have much to add to this...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ... other then I really wasn't that picky about my "One More Thing" today. And...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's amazing, though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: ... Dan offered this one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome to my world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Could they eat the bird? I mean...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. Anyway...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you just mailed in one day. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Here we go. So nutritionists always tell you stay away from fast food. But guess what? Turns out one of America's guilty pleasures might come with some health benefits. Japanese scientists are now using a chemical found in McDonald's French fries to grow hair. The chemical is used to stop cooking oil from foaming. So far researchers have only used it on bald mice, but they believe their groundbreaking findings may also work on people. So you can be fat, greasy, and hairy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now you have food in your hair instead of hair your food.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.utterance: I thought we were going to get family pictures.

utterances.utterance: I'm going to supersize it.

utterances.utterance: All right. So here's what I'm doing today. You know, I don't really cook at home, but I got a great new cookbook from our friend Dion, one of our colleagues here. I actually think that I might do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're going to cook it for Peter or Jasper?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, just for -- just for Jasper.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Cooking for your dog.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Shannon Bream cooked for her dog,

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not going to far?

utterances.utterance: It was a lab, and it lived to be almost 18.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
